revision.text:
{{globalize/US|date=September 2018}} [[File:Tom Bell's graph showing extension of U.S. copyright term over time.svg|thumb|right|360px|Expansion of U.S. copyright term (Assuming authors create their works at age 35 and live for 70 years)]] '''Copyright term''' is the length of time [[copyright]] subsists in a work before it passes into the [[public domain]].
==Length of copyright== Copyright subsists for a variety of lengths in different jurisdictions. The length of the term can depend on several factors, including the type of work (e.g. [[musical composition]] or [[novel]]), whether the work has been published or not, and whether the work was created by an individual or a corporation. In most of the world, the default length of copyright is the life of the author plus either 50 or 70 years. In the United States, the term for most existing works is a fixed number of years after the date of creation or publication. In most countries (for example, the United States<ref>{{usc|17|305}}</ref> and the United Kingdom<ref>{{cite web|website=The Duration of Copyright and Rights in Performances Regulations |date=1995|url=http://www.opsi.gov.uk/si/si1995/Uksi_19953297_en_3.htm |title=Amendments of the UK Copyright, Designs and Patents Act 1988}}</ref>) copyright expires at the end of the calendar year in question.
The length and requirements for copyright duration are subject to change by legislation, and since the early 20th century there have been a number of adjustments made in various countries, which can make determining the copyright duration in a given country difficult. For example, the United States used to require copyrights to be renewed after 28 years to stay in force, and formerly required a copyright notice upon first publication to gain coverage. In Italy and France, there were post-wartime extensions that could increase the term by approximately six years in Italy and up to about 14 in France. Many countries have extended the length of their copyright terms (sometimes [[Ex post facto law|retroactively]]). International treaties, like the [[Berne Convention]], establish minimum terms for copyrights, but these only apply to the signatory countries, and individual countries may grant longer terms than those set out in a treaty.<ref>{{cite book |title=Copyright: Sacred Text, Technology, and the DMCA |last=Nimmer |first=David |publisher=Kluwer Law International |year=2003 |isbn=978-90-411-8876-2 |oclc=50606064 |page=63 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RYfRCNxgPO4C}}</ref>
== Implications == ===Copyright term and the public domain=== The extension of copyright term, imposes tangible restrictions on the [[public domain]]. For instance, scholar Neil Netanel argued that [[Copyright Term Extension Act]] 1998 prevented the entering of works central to [[Culture of the United States|cultural heritage of the US]] into the public domain. He argued, culturally important dissemination, recasting, or incorporation into new expression is prevented due "to the copyright holder's veto". As examples he gave the adaption of the plot from novels such as [[The Great Gatsby]] and [[Peter Pan]], the refashion of characters like [[Mickey Mouse]], or the use of [[Tin Pan Alley]] songs like "[[Let's Do It (Let's Fall in Love)]]" for documentaries about the [[Great Depression]].<ref name=nethanel>{{Cite book| last = Netanel| first = Neil| title = Copyright’s paradox| publisher = Oxford University Press US| date = 2008| pages = 200| url = http://www.google.com/books?id=vo9G-0iZNQIC&dq=orphan+works&source=gbs_navlinks_s| isbn = 9780195137620 }}</ref>
===Copyright term and orphan works=== For the millions of older copyrighted works of less enduring popularity, it is difficult, or impossible, to trace the copyright ownership and determine who holds the particular rights that would have to be licensed for the use of the work. The problem of such [[orphan works]] stems from the extension of copyright term and the lack of requirement for the copyright owner to renew or [[Copyright registration|register their copyright]].<ref name=nethanel/> In order to tackle this perceived problem some jurisdictions have [[Copyright reform|revised their copyright laws]] to allow use of orphaned works, after diligent searches.<ref>[http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/1988/48/chapter/III/crossheading/orphan-works] Copyright Designs and Patents Act 1988, s44B</ref>
==Reception and discussion== Discussions about the optimal length of the copyright term (e.g. regarding the copyrights incentive for creative production<ref name="petra moser">[https://web.archive.org/web/20130214025845/http://www.wipo.int/edocs/mdocs/mdocs/en/wipo_ip_econ_ge_5_12/wipo_ip_econ_ge_5_12_ref_moser.pdf DEAD POETS’ PROPERTY - THE COPYRIGHT ACT OF 1814 AND THE PRICE OF LITERATURE IN THE ROMANTIC PERIOD] XING LI,STANFORD UNIVERSITY, MEGAN MACGARVIE, BOSTON UNIVERSITY AND NBER, AND PETRA MOSER, STANFORD UNIVERSITY AND NBER (NOVEMBER 14, 2012)</ref>) is a significant part of public and scientific discourse and reception.<ref name="JASSS"/><ref>[http://www.economist.com/node/15868004 Copyright and wrong - Why the rules on copyright need to return to their roots] on [[The Economist]] ''"The notion that lengthening copyright increases creativity is questionable, however. Authors and artists do not generally consult the statute books before deciding whether or not to pick up pen or paintbrush. And overlong copyrights often limit, rather than encourage, a work's dissemination, impact and influence."'' (Apr 8th 2010)</ref><ref>[http://www.becker-posner-blog.com/2012/09/do-patent-and-copyright-law-restrict-competition-and-creativity-excessively-posner.html Do patent and copyright law restrict competition and creativity excessively?] on [[University of Chicago Law School]] by Becker & Posner ''"I am concerned that both patent and copyright protection, though particularly the former, may be excessive."'' (2012)</ref><ref name="HoEoC">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RgKZBAAAQBAJ&lpg=PA95&ots=4i2badKPPW&dq=rufus%20pollock%2015%20years&pg=PA10#v=onepage&q=rufus%20pollock%2015%20years&f=false |title=Handbook on the Economics of Copyright: A Guide for Students and Teachers |first=Richard |last=Watt |publisher=Edward Elgar Publishing |date=September 26, 2014 |accessdate=2015-01-11}}</ref><ref>https://www.techdirt.com/articles/20130114/20344621680/new-research-extending-copyright-massively-increases-prices-limits-dissemination-knowledge.shtml</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2013/02/18/open_and_shut/|title=John Lennon's lesson for public-domain innovation - IP protection hurting, not helping, US and UK |date=18 Feb 2013 |author=Matt Asay |accessdate=2017-01-02 |quote=TechDirt highlights research showing that extending copyrights increases prices and limits dissemination of knowledge, while also pointing out that people who believe patents cause innovation are simply confusing correlation with causation. If anything, patents inhibit innovation. |publisher=[[The Register]]}}</ref>
One of the earlier and often cited positions is from the British politician [[Thomas Babington Macaulay]] who argued in an 1841 speech in the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] that copyright is a [[monopoly]] and as such has generally negative effects on society.<ref>[http://homepages.law.asu.edu/~dkarjala/OpposingCopyrightExtension/commentary/MacaulaySpeeches.html MacaulaySpeeches] on law.asu.edu</ref><ref>[http://www.thepublicdomain.org/2014/07/24/macaulay-on-copyright/ macaulay-on-copyright] on thepublicdomain.org</ref> Although Macaulay's speech is widely reported, the reaction to it in the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] is hard to find – Ricketson reports that following Macaulay's claims that the heirs of certain authors would block publication of their works:
:"At this point, the debate in the House of Commons fell into farce because there were claims by other speakers that they had no doubts (based on their own personal knowledge) that Richardson and Boswell's descendants would still have done the right thing and allowed reprinting, however much they abhorred their ancestors' works!"<ref>Sam Ricketson, The copyright term, International Review of Intellectual Property and Competition Law (1992), 753, p767.</ref>
It is also worth noting that Macaulay is arguing here against term extension, he is not arguing against copyright. This point is well made by Macaulay himself:
:"The advantages arising from a system of copyright are obvious. It is desirable that we should have a supply of good books: we cannot have such a supply unless men of letters are liberally remunerated; and the least objectionable way of remunerating them is by means of copyright."<ref>Thomas Babington Macaulay, Speeches of Lord Macaulay, Longman, Green, Longman and Roberts, 1860, p232.</ref>
Liebowitz describes use of the term monopoly in relation to copyright as misleading, but "rhetorically effective".<ref>Stan Liebowitz, A critique of copyright criticism, George Mason Law Review, vol 22:4:943 (2015), p958.</ref> While Towse writes that a more appropriate term is '[[monopolistic competition]]'.<ref>Ruth Towse, Copyright, risk and the artist: an economic approach to policy for artists, International Journal of Cultural Policy, 6:1:91 (1999), p105, note 9.</ref>
In 2009, a paper by [[Rufus Pollock]] of [[University of Cambridge]] scientifically quantified the optimal copyright term length at 15 years, significantly shorter than any currently existing copyright term, via an economical model with [[U-statistic|empirically-estimable parameter]]s.<ref name="HoEoC"/><ref>{{cite web |archivedate=2013-02-21 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130221124708/http://rufuspollock.org/economics/papers/optimal_copyright_over_time.pdf |url=http://rufuspollock.org/economics/papers/optimal_copyright_term.pdf |title=OPTIMAL COPYRIGHT OVER TIME: TECHNOLOGICAL CHANGE AND THE STOCK OF WORKS |first=Rufus |last=Pollock |publisher=[[University of Cambridge]] |date=2007-10-01 |accessdate=2015-01-11 |authorlink=Rufus Pollock |quote=''The optimal level for copyright has been a matter for extensive debate over the last decade. Using a parsimonious theoretical model this paper contributes several new results of relevance to this debate. In particular we demonstrate that (a) optimal copyright is likely to fall as the production costs of `originals' decline (for example as a result of digitization) (b) technological change which reduces costs of production may imply a decrease or a decrease in optimal levels of protection (this contrasts with a large number of commentators, particularly in the copyright industries, who have argued that such change necessitates increases in protection) (c) the optimal level of copyright will, in general, fall over time as the stock of work increases.''}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |archivedate=2013-01-12 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130112152530/http://rufuspollock.org/economics/papers/optimal_copyright_term.pdf |url=http://rufuspollock.org/economics/papers/optimal_copyright_term.pdf |title=FOREVER MINUS A DAY? CALCULATING OPTIMAL COPYRIGHT TERM |first=Rufus |last=Pollock |publisher=[[University of Cambridge]] |date=2009-06-15 |accessdate=2015-01-11 |authorlink=Rufus Pollock |quote=''The optimal term of copyright has been a matter for extensive debate over the last decade. Based on a novel approach we derive an explicit formula which characterises the optimal term as a function of a few key and, most importantly, empirically-estimable parameters. Using existing data on recordings and books we obtain a point estimate of around 15 years for optimal copyright term with a 99% confidence interval extending up to 38 years. This is substantially shorter than any current copyright term and implies that existing terms are too long.''}}</ref>
In 2013 scholar Petra Moser concluded in a paper on the impact of the copyright extension on the British [[Copyright Act 1814|Copyright Act of 1814]] that "longer copyrights raise the costs of accessing intellectual assets for consumers and other firms, which may discourage the diffusion of knowledge and decelerate the pace of cumulative innovation and [[Learning-by-doing (economics)|learning-by-doing]]."<ref name="petra moser"/>
In 2014 a [[Rock, Paper, Shotgun]] article about the existence of [[Orphaned works|orphaned]] classical [[video game]]s and the suggestion of letting them enter the public domain after 20 years, raised a controversial public debate about copyright terms and public domain<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2014/01/29/gogs-time-machine-sale-lets-you-control-time-itself/ |title=GOG’s Time Machine Sale Lets You CONTROL TIME ITSELF |first=John |last=Walker |date=2014-01-29 |accessdate=2016-01-30 |publisher=[[Rock, Paper, Shotgun]] |quote=''As someone who desperately pines for the PD model that drove creativity before the copyright industry malevolently took over the planet, it saddens my heart that a game two decades old isn’t released into the world.''}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2014/02/03/editorial-why-games-should-enter-the-public-domain/ |title=Editorial: Why Games Should Enter The Public Domain |first=John |last=Walker |date=2014-02-03 |accessdate=2016-01-30 |publisher=[[Rock, Paper, Shotgun]] |quote=''games more than a couple of decades old aren’t entering the public domain. Twenty years was a fairly arbitrary number, one that seems to make sense in the context of games’ lives, but it could be twenty-five, thirty.''}}</ref><ref>[https://games.slashdot.org/story/14/02/04/1559230/why-games-should-be-in-the-public-domain Why Games Should Be In the Public Domain] on [[slashdot]].com</ref> between game industry veterans [[John Walker (journalist)|John Walker]], [[George Broussard]], and Steve Gaynor.<ref>[https://twitter.com/georgeb3dr/statuses/428565882608967680 George Broussard] on [[Twitter]] ''"@wickerwaka The whole thing, really. But especially that. Whoever allowed that to be printed should be fired."''</ref><ref>[http://www.gamasutra.com/blogs/SteveGaynor/20140203/209927/Copyright_trademark__money_in_a_creative_industry.php Copyright, trademark & money in a creative industry] on [[gamasutra]].com by Steve Gaynor ''"There is some argument going on about for how long a copyright holder should be able to charge exclusively for their own work, before it enters the public domain. John Walker argues that perhaps a good cutoff would be 20 years before an "idea" enters the public domain."'' (February 03, 2014)</ref>
A March 2015 published [[Journal of Artificial Societies and Social Simulation]] paper, analysed with a simulated model the relationship of scientific knowledge creation to copyright term length and concluded a decreased knowledge production on copyright term increases for the analysed context.<ref name="JASSS">[http://jasss.soc.surrey.ac.uk/18/2/23.html Does Longer Copyright Protection Help or Hurt Scientific Knowledge Creation?] [[Journal of Artificial Societies and Social Simulation]] 18 (2) 23 DOI: 10.18564/jasss.2720 ''"The prevailing trend in most simulations was that increasing the copyright term resulted decreased knowledge production."'' (31-Mar-2015)</ref>
As a curiosity, the work ''[[Peter and Wendy#Copyright status|Peter Pan, or The Boy Who Wouldn't Grow Up]]'' is subject in the UK to a special clause in the [[Copyright Designs and Patents Act 1988]]<ref>Copyright Designs and Patents Act 1988 s301 and schedule 6.</ref> that granted [[Great Ormond Street Hospital]] a right to royalty in perpetuity. [[J M Barrie]] had gifted the copyright to the work to the hospital in 1929. The different copyright terms in the various jurisdictions has led to some disputes involving derivative works created and/or sold elsewhere in the world.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cyberlaw.stanford.edu/about/cases/emily_somma_v_gosh_peter_.shtml |title=Stanford Center for Internet and Society |publisher=Web.archive.org |accessdate=2010-05-08 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061027134508/http://cyberlaw.stanford.edu/about/cases/emily_somma_v_gosh_peter_.shtml |archivedate = 2006-10-27}}</ref>
==Charts== Several charts have been made to help decipher the various copyright terms in the United States, such as: *Tom W. Bell's ''Trend of Maximum U.S. General Copyright Term'' (July 23, 2008)<ref>{{cite web|author=Bell, Tom W.|url=http://www.tomwbell.com/writings/%28C%29_Term.html |title=Copyright Term Chart: Trend of Maximum U.S. General Copyright Term |website=TomWBell.com |date=July 23, 2008 }}</ref> *Clorox (diskussion)'s ''Vectorization of Tom Bell's graph'', depicted above, which shows expansion of U.S. copyright law (November 27, 2008)<ref>{{cite book|author=Clorox (diskussion)|author2=Bell, Tom. W.|last-author-amp=yes|date=November 27, 2008|title=Vectorization of Tom Bell's graph, which shows expansion of U.S. copyright law}}</ref> *Peter B. Hirtle's ''Copyright Term and the Public Domain in the United States'' (2015)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://copyright.cornell.edu/resources/publicdomain.cfm |title=Copyright Term and the Public Domain in the United States |author=Hirtle, Peter B. |website=Cornell.edu |date=January 1, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150226112433/http://copyright.cornell.edu/resources/publicdomain.cfm |archivedate=February 26, 2015 |df= }}</ref> *Sunstein, Kann, Murphy & Timbers, LLP's ''Copyright Flowchart'' (2014)<ref>{{cite web|date=2014|title=Copyright Flowchart: Flowchart for determining when U.S. copyrights in fixed works expire|url=http://sunsteinlaw.com/practices/copyright-portfolio-development/copyright-pointers/copyright-flowchart/ |website=WINNING INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY® |author=Sunstein, Kann, Murphy & Timbers LLP}}</ref>
== See also == *[[History of copyright law]] *[[List of countries' copyright length]] *[[Perpetual copyright]] *[[Rule of the shorter term]] *[[Copyright Term Extension Act]]

[[Image:Serres-dominic.jpg|thumb|'''Dominic Serres''' (1722–1793), by Philip Jean, 1788 (National Portrait Gallery, London)]] '''Dominic Serres''' [[Royal Academy|RA]] (1722–1793), also known as Dominic Serres the Elder, was a [[France|French]]-born [[Painting|painter]] strongly associated with the [[English school of painting]], and with paintings with a naval or marine theme. Such were his connections with the English art world, that he became one of the founding members of the [[Royal Academy]] in 1768, and was later briefly (from 1792 until his death) its librarian.
Born in [[Auch]], [[Gascony]], he was initially expected to train as a priest but instead travelled to [[Spain]] and became a ship’s captain, sailing to [[Cuba]]. He was taken prisoner by the British navy towards the end of the 1740s and eventually settled in [[London]] in about 1758, where it is believed he trained as a painter in [[Northamptonshire]] and later in [[London]] under [[Charles Brooking]]. If Serres did not settle in London until 1758, however, he could not have studied for long under Charles Brooking, since Brooking was buried on 25 March 1759.
Reflecting his early career, many of his paintings have naval themes. Working for a publisher documenting the events in the [[Seven Years' War]] (1756–1763), he painted a series of depictions including the capture of [[Havana]] (1762). He also painted events in the [[United States|America]]n [[American War of Independence|War of Independence]] (1776–1783). In 1780, he was appointed Marine Painter to King [[George III of the United Kingdom|George III]].
Serres died in 1793, and was buried at St. [[St Marylebone Parish Church|Marylebone]] Old Church. His eldest son [[John Thomas Serres]] (1759–1825) also became a prolific marine artist.
<gallery> Image:The Battle of Quiberon Bay.jpg|The [[Battle of Quiberon Bay]], 20 November 1759 Image:PenobscotExpeditionBySerres.jpg|[[Penobscot Expedition]] (1779) File:Halifax1762ByDominicSerres.jpg|[[Halifax Regional Municipality|Halifax, Nova Scotia c.1762]] File:Halifaxc1762byDominicSerres.jpg|[[Halifax Regional Municipality|Halifax, Nova Scotia c.1762]] File:British fleet entering Havana.jpg|[[Battle of Havana (1762)]] File:Halifax1777ByDominicSerres.jpg|[[Halifax Regional Municipality|Halifax, Nova Scotia c.1777]] File:Dominic Serres - Saint Vincents, near West Malling, Kent - Google Art Project.jpg|Saint Vincents, near West Malling, Kent File:Dominic Serres - An English Two-Decker Lying Hove to, with Other Ships and Vessels in a Fresh Breeze - Google Art Project.jpg| The Lying Hove File:The Defeat of the French Fireships attacking the British Fleet at Anchor before Quebec.jpg|[[Battle of Quebec (1759)]] </gallery>
==References== *{{DNB|wstitle=Serres, Dominic}}
==Further reading== *Russett, Alan. ''Dominic Serres 1719 - 1793: War Artist to the Navy'' (Antiques Collectors Club, 2001).
==External links== {{commons category}} * {{Art UK bio}} *[http://www.artcyclopedia.com/artists/serres_dominic.html Dominic Serres online] (ArtCyclopedia) *[http://www.racollection.org.uk/ixbin/indexplus?record=ART372 Dominic Serres] (Biography and works at the [[Royal Academy of Arts]], London). *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110608072858/http://www.nmm.ac.uk/collections/explore/people.cfm/id/161996 Serres biography and works] ([[National Maritime Museum]], London) *[http://freepages.family.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~londonaye/serres_family.htm Serres ancestry] ("rootsweb") *[http://www.christies.com/LotFinder/lot_details.aspx?intObjectID=5127577 An English man-o'war shortening sail entering Portsmouth harbour] (painting - exhibited in 1778)
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Serres, Dominic}} [[Category:1722 births]] [[Category:1793 deaths]] [[Category:18th-century French painters]] [[Category:French male painters]] [[Category:Marine artists]] [[Category:Royal Academicians]]

revision.text:
[[File:TombofNebamun-2.jpg|thumb|[[Nebamun]] hunting birds in the marshes using cats, fragment of a scene from the [[Tomb of Nebamun|tomb-chapel of Nebamun]], [[Thebes, Egypt|Thebes]], [[Egypt]] Late [[Eighteenth Dynasty of Egypt|18th Dynasty]], around 1350 BC.<ref name="British MuseumNebamun" />]] '''Hierarchical proportion''' is a technique used in art, mostly in [[sculpture]] and [[painting]], in which the artist uses unnatural [[Body proportions|proportion]] or [[scale (ratio)|scale]] to depict the relative importance of the figures in the artwork.
For example, in [[Ancient Egypt|Egyptian]] times, people of higher status would sometimes be drawn or sculpted larger than those of lower status.
During the Dark Ages, people with more status had larger proportions than serfs. During the Renaissance images of the human body began to change proportion was used to depict the reality an artist interpreted.
==Gallery== <gallery widths="220px" perrow="3"> File:Narmer-Tjet2.JPG|The [[Narmer Palette]] - [[Obverse and reverse|obverse]] side, [[Early Dynastic Period of Egypt]], about the 31st century BC File:Victory stele of Naram Sin 9062.jpg|Victory [[stele]] of [[Naram-Sin of Akkad|Naram Sin]], the [[Akkadian Empire]] in ancient [[Mesopotamia]], 2350 - 2000 BC File:BD Weighing of the Heart.jpg|The Weighing of the Heart from the [[Papyrus of Ani|Book of the Dead of Ani]], [[Nineteenth Dynasty of Egypt|19th dynasty]] of the [[New Kingdom of Egypt|New Kingdom of ancient Egypt]], c. 1250 B.C. File:Cancuenpanel3.jpg|Panel 3 from [[Maya civilization|Maya]] city [[Cancuén]] portraying the ruler [[Tajal Chan Ahk]], 8th-century File:Meister der Reichenauer Schule 002.jpg|[[Otto III]] from the [[Gospels of Otto III]], [[Reichenau Island|Reichenau Abbey]] in southern [[Germany]], late 10th or early 11th century File:Autun St Lazare Tympanon.jpg|[[Last Judgement]] by [[Gislebertus]] in the west [[Tympanum (architecture)|tympanum]] of the [[Autun Cathedral]] in [[France]], 1120 - 1146. File:Duccio maesta1021.jpg|[[Maestà (Duccio)|Maestà of Duccio]], [[Siena]], [[Italy]], 1308 – 1311 File:Hugo van der Goes 004.jpg|[[Portinari Altarpiece]], [[Flemish painter]] [[Hugo van der Goes]] for the church of the [[hospital of Santa Maria Nuova]] in [[Florence]] in [[Italy]], c. 1475. File:Brooklyn Museum - Zumurrud Shah Takes Refuge in the Mountains - overall.jpg|Zumurrud Shah takes refuge in the mountains ([[India]], ca. 1570, illustration to [[Hamzanama]] <ref name="Hamzanama" />) File:Brooklyn Museum - Battle of Karbala - Abbas Al-Musavi - overall.jpg|[[Battle of Karbala]], [[Hussein ibn Ali|Imam Husayn’s]] half brother [[Al-Abbas ibn Ali|Abbas Al-Musavi]] in focus, [[Isfahan]], [[Iran]], late 19th - early 20th century <ref name="BrooklynMuseumKarbala" /> </gallery>
==References== :*''Artforms'' by Preble, Preble, Frank; Prentice Hall 2004

<ref name="British MuseumNebamun">{{cite web |url = https://www.britishmuseum.org/explore/highlights/highlight_objects/aes/n/nebamun_hunting_in_the_marshes.aspx |title = British Museum - Nebamun hunting in the marshes, fragment of a scene from the tomb-chapel of Nebamun |publisher = British Museum |location= London |accessdate= 7 July 2013 }}</ref>
<ref name="BrooklynMuseumKarbala">{{cite web |url = http://www.brooklynmuseum.org/opencollection/objects/3054/Battle_of_Karbala |title = Brooklyn Museum: Arts of the Islamic World: Battle of Karbala |publisher = Brooklyn Museum |location= Brooklyn, New York |accessdate= 7 July 2013 }}</ref>
<ref name="Hamzanama">{{cite web |url = http://www.asia.si.edu/exhibitions/online/hamza/ |title = The adventures of Hamza |publisher = Smithsonian Institution |location=Washington, D.C. |accessdate= 7 July 2013 }}</ref>
}}

revision.text:
{{Cleanup|date=April 2009}} {{Hinduism}} '''Hindu art''' encompasses the artistic traditions and styles culturally connected to [[Hinduism]] and have a long history of religious association with Hindu scriptures, rituals and worship.
==Background== [[Hinduism]], with its [[Hinduism by country|1 billion followers]], it makes up about 15% of the world’s population<ref>{{cite web|title=The Global Religious Landscape - Hinduism|url=http://www.pewforum.org/global-religious-landscape-hindu.aspx|work=A Report on the Size and Distribution of the World’s Major Religious Groups as of 2010|publisher=The pew foundation|accessdate=31 March 2013}}</ref> and as such the culture that ensues it is full of different aspects of life that are effected by art. There are 64 traditional arts that are followed that start with the classics of music and range all the way to the application and adornment of jewelry.<ref>”Heart of Hinduism: Sanskrit and Sanskriti (Culture).” 2004, 30 Mar 2009. < http://hinduism.iskcon.com/lifestyle/801.htm>.</ref> Since religion and culture are inseparable with Hinduism recurring symbols such as the gods and their reincarnations, the [[Padma (attribute)|lotus]] flower, extra limbs, and even the traditional arts make their appearances in many sculptures, paintings, music, and dance.
{{Hindu_Classical_Arts}}
==Popular Dance and Music Art Forms== [[Natya Shastra]] and centuries of Hindu cultural traditions have given rise to several art forms. Some of which are: *[[Bharatanatyam]] *[[Kuchipudi]] *[[Manipuri dance | Manipuri]] *[[Mohiniyattam]] *[[Odissi]] *[[Sattriya]] *[[Bhagavata Mela]] *[[Yakshagana]] *[[Carnatic Music]]
[[File:Flower garland sellers outside Banke Bihari Temple, Vrindavan.jpg|thumbnail|floral decoration]] [[File:Guru Sanchita Bhattacharya performing as DURGA.jpg|thumb|right|A Hindu dance depicting the goddess Durga]]
==64 Traditional Arts<ref>Himalayan Academy. “Kala 64: Hindu - Hinduism Dictionary on Kala 64.” 20 Apr 2009 < http://www.experiencefestival.com/a/Kala_64/id/60455>.</ref>== [[File:BHANUSINGAR PADAVALI DANCE BALLET DSC 3649.JPG|thumb|right|Hindu dances as part of ritual]] *Singing *Instrumental music **Learning music in [[Hindu culture]] was a difficult task before the 20th century because of a necessary birth into a [[gharana]]. After the early 1920s integration of anyone wanting to learn classical Hindustani music could. An average ensemble normally includes a harmonium (which was brought to India by westerners), flute, [[veena]], [[sitar]], swaramandala, and a tabla. Many of the songs have strong themes that are related to theology such as a god’s favorite pastimes, praise of any god whether they be in their original form from “the trinity” or the god's reincarnation, even stories of the creation of earth. Since instrumental music is a performance art it must follow strict guidelines that come from the treatise Natya Shastra.<ref>Dr. Beck, Guy. “Hindu music, now and into the future.” Hinduism Today October/November/December 2007. 28-31. < http://www.hinduismtoday.com/modules/smartsection/item.php?itemid=1515></ref> *Dancing *Painting **Indian variety - the different types of folk paintings are proud for Indian culture which reflects beauty, tradition and heritage of India. There are many types of traditional paintings like [[Madhubani art|Madhubani]], Rajsthani, [[Batik|Batik-Art]], Patachitra, Gond, Mandala, [[Warli|Tribal Art Warli]], [[Pithora (painting)|Pithora]], Bengali, Nirmal, [[Mysore painting|Mysore]], [[Tanjore]] paintings etc. which are the expressions of love, almighty, beauty, truth, tradition and art of each and every region of the India. *Forehead adornments *Making decorative floral and grain designs on the floor *Home and temple flower arranging *Personal grooming *Mosaic tiling *Bedroom arrangements *Creating music with water *Splashing and squirting with water *Secret mantras *Making flower garlands *Head adornments *Dressing **Drapery- The art of drapery has progressed over time. At one point both men and women wore dhotis but around the 14th century that changed and women’s fashion became more intricate thus creating the sari. The drapery involved distinguishes the wearer’s taste, occupation, and social status. The fabrics chosen range from cotton and synthetic fabrics all the way to silk. The fabric chosen depends on what occasion the wearer is going to use the item of clothing for. The draping of the sari comes in four different families: [[Marvari]], [[Dravidian peoples|Dravidian]], Tribal, and Nivi. The family that the wearer chooses depends on the wearer’s personal taste. The way an item of clothing is draped tells a lot about the wearer such as expression of creativity, progression of fashion, and where the user comes from.<ref>Boulanger, Chantal. “The Remarkable Indian Art of Draping.” Hinduism Today. October/November/December 2008. 60-62. <http://www.hinduismtoday.com/modules/smartsection/item.php?itemid=3078></ref> *Costume decorations *Perfumery *Jewelry making *Magic and illusions *Ointments for charm and virility *Manual dexterity *Skills of cooking, eating and drinking *Beverage and dessert preparation *Sewing (making and mending garments) *Embroidery *Playing Vina and drum *Riddles and rhymes *Poetry games *Tongue twisters and difficult recitation *Literary recitation *Drama and story telling **Drama in its early essence was performed mainly by male troupes and was often integrated with many of the other traditional art forms such as poetry, music, and story telling. Since drama is a performance art it also follows the [[Natya Shastra]] guidelines.<ref>“Dance and Drama.” Heart of Hinduism. 2004, 12 Mar 2009. < http://hinduism.iskcon.com/lifestyle/803.htm></ref> *Verse composition games *Furniture caning *Erotic devices and knowledge of sexual arts *Crafting wooden furniture *Architecture and house construction *Distinguishing between ordinary and precious stones and metals *Metal-working *Gems and mining *Gardening and horticulture *Games of wager involving animals *Training parrots and mynas to speak *Hairdressing *Coding messages *Speaking in code *Knowledge of foreign languages and dialects *Making flower carriages *Spells, charms and omens *Making simple mechanical devices *Memory training *Game of reciting verses from hearing *Decoding messages *The meanings of words *Dictionary studies *Prosody and rhetoric *Impersonation *Artful dressing *Games of dice *The game of akarsha (a dice game played on a board) *Making dolls and toys for children *Personal etiquette and animal training *Knowledge of dharmic warfare and victory *Physical culture
The names and meanings of all the 64 Arts
(1) gita — art of singing.
(2) vadya — art of playing on musical instruments.
(3) nritya — art of dancing.
(4) natya — art of theatricals.
(5) alekhya — art of painting.
(6) viseshakacchedya — art of painting the face and body with colored unguents and cosmetics.
(7) tandula-kusuma-bali-vikara — art of preparing offerings from rice and flowers.
(8) pushpastarana — art of making a covering of flowers for a bed.
(9) dasana-vasananga-raga — art of applying preparations for cleansing the teeth, cloths and painting the body.
(10) mani-bhumika-karma — art of making the jewel garlands.
(11) sayya-racana — art of covering the bed.
(12) udaka-vadya — art of playing on music in water.
(13) udaka-ghata — art of splashing water on ground.
(14) citra-yoga — art of practically applying an admixture of colors.
(15) malya-grathana-vikalpa — art of designing a preparation of wreaths or garlands.
(16) sekharapida-yojana — art of practically setting the coronet on the head.
(17) nepathya-yoga — art of practically dressing
(18) karnapatra-bhanga — art of decorating the tragus of the ear.
(19) sugandha-yukti — art of practical application of aromatics.
(20) bhushana-yojana — art of applying or setting ornaments.
(21) aindra-jala — art of jugglery.
(22) kaucumara — a kind of art.
(23) hasta-laghava — art of sleight of hand.
(24) citra-sakapupa-bhakshya-vikara-kriya — art of preparing varieties of foods - curries, soups, sweetmeats
(25) panaka-rasa-ragasava-yojana — art of preparing palatable drinks and fruit juices
(26) suci-vaya-karma — art of needleworks and weaving.
(27) sutra-krida — art of playing with thread.
(28) vina-damuraka-vadya — art of playing on lute and small x-shaped drum.
(29) prahelika — art of making and solving riddles. (29-a) pratimala — art of caping or reciting verse for verse as a trial for memory or skill.
(30) durvacaka-yoga — art of practicing language difficult to be answered by others.
(31) pustaka-vacana — art of reciting books.
(32) natikakhyayika-darsana — art of enacting short plays and anecdotes.
(33) kavya-samasya-purana — art of solving enigmatic verses.
(34) pattika-vetra-bana-vikalpa — art of designing preparation of shield, cane and arrows.
(35) tarku-karma — art of spinning by spindle.
(36) takshana — art of carpentry.
(37) vastu-vidya — art of engineering.
(38) raupya-ratna-pariksha — art of testing silver and jewels.
(39) dhatu-vada — art of metallurgy.
(40) mani-raga jnana — art of judging jewels.
(41) akara jnana — art of mineralogy.
(42) vrikshayur-veda-yoga — art of practicing medicine or medical treatment, by herbs.
(43) mesha-kukkuta-lavaka-yuddha-vidhi — art of knowing the mode of fighting of lambs, cocks and birds.
(44) suka-sarika-prapalana (pralapana)? — art of maintaining or knowing conversation between male and female cockatoos.
(45) utsadana — art of healing or cleaning a person with perfumes.
(46) kesa-marjana-kausala — art of combing hair.
(47) akshara-mushtika-kathana — art of talking with fingers.
(48) mlecchita-kutarka-vikalpa — art of fabricating barbarous or foreign sophistry.
(49) desa-bhasha-jnana — art of knowing provincial dialects.
(50) pushpa-sakatika-nirmiti-jnana — art of knowing prediction by heavenly voice or knowing preparation of toy carts by flowers.
(51) yantra-matrika — art of mechanics.
(52) dharana-matrika — art of the use of amulets.
(53) samvacya — art of conversation.
(54) manasi kavya-kriya — art of composing verse mentally.
(55) kriya-vikalpa — art of designing a literary work or a medical remedy.
(56) chalitaka-yoga — art of practicing as a builder of shrines
(57) abhidhana-kosha-cchando-jnana — art of the use of lexicography and meters.
(58) vastra-gopana — art of concealment of cloths.
(59) dyuta-visesha — art of knowing specific gambling.
(60) akarsha-krida — art of playing with dice or magnet.
(61) balaka-kridanaka — art of using children’s toys.
(62) vainayiki vidya — art of enforcing discipline.
(63) vaijayiki vidya — art of gaining victory.
(64) vaitaliki vidya — art of awakening master with music at dawn
(65) aaaah vidya — art of awakening sound from Mani.
==Historic Texts on Art Practices==
*Natya Shastra **The Natya Shastra is the leading guide to the Hindu performing arts. It is based on the Natya Veda, which no longer exists, and is roughly 37 chapters long with 6,000 [[slokas]].<ref>“Natya Shastra: Encyclopedia II.” 29 Apr 2009. < http://www.experiencefestival.com/a/Natya_Shastra_-_Text_and_title/id/1793036></ref>
==Cities Dedicated to the Production of Art==
*Raghupajpur **This city is solely dedicated to the production of artwork that is driven by the divine forces of Hinduism and these artworks are produced in a traditional fashion. The city is located in Eastern India (Orissa) and at one point this city was at risk of being completely destroyed due to British rule{{citation needed|date=November 2018}}. During this time religion and the power of the kings were being overthrown and as such there was no reason for a city to exist whose main purpose is to supply traditional art. After this crisis occurred the city began to exclusively base itself on agriculture until a man named Jacnnath Mopatra led a training center for chitrakars. This revolution began production of the traditional art works once again in the 1950s and since the work being produced is known internationally.<ref>Dr. Mohanty, M.P. “Living, Painting, Worshipping Art.” Hinduism Today. July/August/September 2007. 54-59. <http://www.hinduismtoday.com/modules/smartsection/item.php?itemid=1562></ref>
==Common Symbols==
*Extra Limbs-Extra limbs are seen on many of the Hindu deities in paintings and sculptures. The extra limbs show how much power the god is capable of because of their ability to perform many tasks at once. Such as the goddess [[Sarasvati]] always has a minimum of four arms. Two of the arms will be playing a vina, representing the tuning of her knowledge, prayer beads in another hand and a scripture in another, both of these items are used to represent her devotion to her spirituality. Since she is the goddess of learning and art we see that she is very capable and very powerful in her area of expertise.<ref>Stephen Knapp. “Saravasti, the Goddess of Learning.” 20 Mar 2009. < http://www.stephen-knapp.com/sarasvati_goddess_of_learning.htm></ref> *Lotus Flower-The lotus flower is another common item seen constantly throughout the arts. The lotus flower represents purity, beauty, prosperity, fertility, and transcendence.<ref>Anil K. Goel, Lucknow. “God’s Favorite Flower.” Hinduism Today. 1999. 15 Apr 2009. < http://www.hinduismtoday.com/modules/smartsection/item.php?itemid=4411>.</ref> The reason the flower shows these attributes is due to the process in which the lotus flower goes through in order to blossom. The flower grows out of mud and rests atop the water in which it grows showing the hardship it must endure in order to achieve maximum beauty. Many deities have their name based on the Sanskrit word for lotus such as Lakshimi.<ref>“Lotus-Hindu Symbols” Religion Facts. 2007. 15 Apr 2009. < http://www.religionfacts.com/hinduism/symbols/lotus.htm>.</ref>
==See also== *[[Kalā]] *[[Alpana]] *[[Balinese art]] *[[Art of Champa]] *[[Jnana Vigraham]] *[[Madhubani art]] *[[Rangoli]] *[[Tanjore painting]]
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.text:
This is a page containing all available sales and awards from [[industrial rock]] and [[industrial metal]] artists.
This list is far from complete. Many countries were excluded from it because their [[IFPI|Industry Associations]] lacked a searchable, online database. [[Belgium]], [[Iceland]] and [[Mexico]] are some of them.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.ifpi.org/content/section_links/national_associations.html|title= LINKS - National record industry associations|publisher= [[IFPI]]|accessdate= 2007-09-15 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070830111508/http://www.ifpi.org/content/section_links/national_associations.html <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2007-08-30}}</ref> Some [[Europe]]an countries who do have it ([[Greece]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ifpi.gr/charts.htm |title=Charts |publisher=[[IFPI]] |accessdate=2007-09-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100118081907/http://www.ifpi.gr/charts.htm |archivedate=2010-01-18 |df= }}</ref> [[Hungary]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mahasz.hu/m/?menu=arany_es_platinalemezek&menu2=adatbazis |title=Adatbázis |publisher=[Magyae Hanglemezkiadók Szövetsége] |accessdate=2007-09-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070921063531/http://www.mahasz.hu/m/.?menu=arany_es_platinalemezek&menu2=adatbazis |archivedate=2007-09-21 |df= }}</ref> and [[Spain]]<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.promusicae.org|title= Todas las listas|publisher= [Promusicae]|accessdate= 2007-09-17}}</ref>) were excluded anyway, because their databases showed no relevant sales pertaining industrial rock and metal groups. [[Latin American]] countries with online databases ([[Argentina]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.capif.org.ar/Default.asp?CodOp=ESOP&CO=5 |title=ESTADÌSTICAS - Discos de Oro y Platino |publisher=[CAPIF ::: Representando a la Industria Argentina de la Música :::] |accessdate=2007-09-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20110706084412/http://www.capif.org.ar/Default.asp?CodOp=ESOP&CO=5 |archivedate=2011-07-06 |df= }}</ref> and [[Brazil]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.abpd.org.br/certificados.asp |title=Certificados |publisher=[ABPD - Associação Brasileira de Produtores de Disco] |accessdate=2007-09-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100906003856/http://www.abpd.org.br/certificados.asp |archivedate=2010-09-06 |df= }}</ref>) were excluded over the same principle.
== Certifications ==
* [[Austria]]: 10,000 for [[Music recording sales certification|gold]] - 20,000 for [[Music recording sales certification|platinum]] ([[Long play|LPs]]); 15,000 for [[Music recording sales certification|gold]] - 30,000 for [[Music recording sales certification|platinum]] ([[Single (music)|Single]]).<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.ifpi.at/search.php3?n_id= |title = Gold und Platin Datenbank |publisher = [[IFPI]] |accessdate = 2007-09-20 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070928171112/http://www.ifpi.at/search.php3?n_id= |archivedate = 2007-09-28 |df = }}</ref> * [[Australia]]: 35,000 for [[Music recording sales certification|gold]] - 70,000 for [[Music recording sales certification|platinum]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aria.com.au/pages/aria-charts-accreditations.htm |title=ARIA Charts - Accreditations |publisher=[Australian Recording Industry Association] |accessdate=2007-09-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721044303/http://www.aria.com.au/pages/aria-charts-accreditations.htm |archivedate=2011-07-21 |df= }}</ref> * [[Canada]]: 50,000 for [[Music recording sales certification|gold]] - 100,000 for [[Music recording sales certification|platinum]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cria.ca/cert.php |title=Certification Definitions |publisher=[Canadian Recording Industry Association (CRIA)] |accessdate=2007-09-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091124091223/http://www.cria.ca/cert.php |archivedate=2009-11-24 |df= }}</ref> * [[Denmark]]: 15,000 for [[Music recording sales certification|gold]] - 30,000 for [[Music recording sales certification|platinum]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.ifpi.dk/index.php?pk_menu=13|title= Guld og platin|publisher=[[IFPI Denmark]]|accessdate= 2007-09-20}}</ref> * [[Finland]]: 15,000 for [[Music recording sales certification|gold]] - 30,000 for [[Music recording sales certification|platinum]].<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.ifpi.fi/tilastot/myontamisrajat.html|title= Myöntämisrajat |publisher=[[IFPI Finland]]|accessdate= 2007-09-20}}</ref> * [[France]]: ** Before June 2006: 100,000 for [[Music recording sales certification|gold]] - 300,000 for [[Music recording sales certification|platinum]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.disqueenfrance.com/snep/dossiers/2006_06.asp|title= Les certifications de l'année 2005|publisher= [Musique sur Disque en France (SNEP)]|accessdate= 2007-09-20 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070913132459/http://www.disqueenfrance.com/snep/dossiers/2006_06.asp <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2007-09-13}}</ref> ** As of June 2006: 75,000 for [[Music recording sales certification|gold]] - 200,000 for [[Music recording sales certification|platinum]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.disqueenfrance.com/snep/dossiers/2007_01_08.asp|title= Les certifications 2006|publisher= [Musique sur Disque en France (SNEP)]|accessdate= 2007-09-20 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070912203423/http://www.disqueenfrance.com/snep/dossiers/2007_01_08.asp <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2007-09-12}}</ref> * [[Germany]]: ** Before October 27, 2005: 250,000 for [[Music recording sales certification|gold]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rammstein.com/_SimpleBall/Band/Timeline/T1997 |title=TIMELINE: May 23rd, 1997 |publisher=[ RAMMSTEIN :: News] |accessdate=2007-09-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070825203209/http://www.rammstein.com/_SimpleBall/Band/Timeline/T1997/ |archivedate=August 25, 2007 }}</ref> - 500,000 for [[Music recording sales certification|platinum]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rammstein.com/_SimpleBall/Band/Timeline/T1998 |title=TIMELINE: August 24th, 1998 |publisher=[RAMMSTEIN :: News] |accessdate=2007-09-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070825203329/http://www.rammstein.com/_SimpleBall/Band/Timeline/T1998/ |archivedate=August 25, 2007 }}</ref> ** As of October 27, 2005: 100,000 for [[Music recording sales certification|gold]] - 200,000 for [[Music recording sales certification|platinum]] ([[Long play|LPs]]); 150,000 for [[Music recording sales certification|gold]] - 300,000 for [[Music recording sales certification|platinum]] ([[Single (music)|Single]]).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ifpi.de/charts/gp_schall.htm |title=Richtlinien: Schallplatten/CD |publisher=[[IFPI]] |accessdate=2007-09-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930155120/http://www.ifpi.de/charts/gp_schall.htm |archivedate=2007-09-30 |df= }}</ref> *** Music sales in [[Germany]] plummeted 40% from 2001 to 2005,<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2005/07/25/business/media/25music.html|title= Some Industry Advice to German Musicians: Never Mind the English Lessons|author= Pfanner, Eric|date= 2005-07-25|publisher= International Herald Tribune|accessdate= 2007-09-30}} Archived at the [https://www.nytimes.com New York Times]</ref> which is probably the cause for the change in the country's certification system. * [[Netherlands]]: 35,000 for [[Music recording sales certification|gold]] - 70,000 for [[Music recording sales certification|platinum]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.nvpi.nl/nvpi/pagina.asp?pagkey=62772|title= Reglement|publisher= [nvpi]|accessdate= 2007-09-20}}</ref> * [[New Zealand]]: 7,500 for [[Music recording sales certification|gold]] - 15,000 for [[Music recording sales certification|platinum]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rianz.org.nz/rianz/ChartInfo.asp?id=118 |title=Chart Facts |publisher=[RIANZ: recording industry association of new zealand] |accessdate=2007-09-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927230237/http://www.rianz.org.nz/rianz/ChartInfo.asp?id=118 |archivedate=2007-09-27 |df= }}</ref> * [[Norway]]: 15,000 for [[Music recording sales certification|gold]] - 30,000 for [[Music recording sales certification|platinum]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ifpi.no/troferegler.htm |title=TROFÉREGLER |publisher=[[IFPI]] |accessdate=2007-09-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070613014516/http://www.ifpi.no/troferegler.htm |archivedate=2007-06-13 |df= }}</ref> * [[Poland]]: 10,000 for [[Music recording sales certification|gold]] - 20,000 for [[Music recording sales certification|platinum]].<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.zpav.pl/zasady_zpd.asp|title= ZASADY PRZYZNAWANIA ZLOTYCH, PLATYNOWYCH I DIAMENTOWYCH PLYT|publisher= [Zwiazek Producentów Audio-Video]|accessdate= 2007-09-20 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070910230348/http://zpav.pl/zasady_zpd.asp <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2007-09-10}}</ref> * [[Sweden]]: 20,000 for [[Music recording sales certification|gold]] - 40,000 for [[Music recording sales certification|platinum]].<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.ifpi.se/goldplatinum.aspx|title= GULD & PLATINA - Följande är gränserna för Guld respektive Platina|publisher=[[IFPI]]|accessdate= 2007-09-20 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070825002501/http://www.ifpi.se/goldplatinum.aspx <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2007-08-25}}</ref> * [[Switzerland]]:<ref>{{cite web |url=http://swisscharts.com/awards.asp?year=2007 |title=Certifications |publisher=[The Official Swiss Charts and Music Community] |accessdate=2007-09-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130921140302/http://swisscharts.com/awards.asp?year=2007 |archivedate=2013-09-21 |df= }}</ref> ** Until 2000: 25,000 for [[Music recording sales certification|gold]] - 50,000 for [[Music recording sales certification|platinum]]. ** From 2001 to 2005: 20,000 for [[Music recording sales certification|gold]] - 40,000 for [[Music recording sales certification|platinum]]. ** Since 2006: 15,000 for [[Music recording sales certification|gold]] - 30,000 for [[Music recording sales certification|platinum]]. * [[United Kingdom]]: 60,000 for [[Music recording sales certification|silver]] - 100,000 for [[Music recording sales certification|gold]] - 300,000 for [[Music recording sales certification|platinum]].<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.bpi.co.uk/platinum/platintro.html|title= BPI Certified Awards|publisher= [THE BPI]|accessdate= 2007-09-20 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070930225906/http://www.bpi.co.uk/platinum/platintro.html <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2007-09-30}}</ref> * [[United States of America]]: 500,000 for [[Music recording sales certification|gold]] - 1 million for [[Music recording sales certification|platinum]].<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.riaa.com/goldandplatinum.php?content_selector=criteria|title= Criteria|publisher= [RIAA] |accessdate= 2007-09-19}}</ref>
== Australia ==
===[[Australia]]=== Below are the accreditations for the ''[[Australian Recording Industry Association]]'', from 1997 onwards:<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aria.com.au/pages/aria-charts-accreditations.htm |title=ARIA Charts - Accreditations |publisher=[Australian Recording Industry Association] |accessdate=2007-09-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721044303/http://www.aria.com.au/pages/aria-charts-accreditations.htm |archivedate=2011-07-21 |df= }}</ref> {{col-begin-small}} {{col-4}} * [[Marilyn Manson]]: ''[[Antichrist Superstar]]'' (1996): [[Music recording sales certification|gold]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aria.com.au/pages/aria-charts-accreditations-albums-1997.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-01-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080528162635/http://www.aria.com.au/pages/aria-charts-accreditations-albums-1997.htm |archivedate=2008-05-28 |df= }}</ref> * [[Marilyn Manson]]: ''[[Mechanical Animals]]'' (1998): [[Music recording sales certification|gold]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aria.com.au/pages/aria-charts-accreditations-albums-1998.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-01-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110611210013/http://www.aria.com.au/pages/aria-charts-accreditations-albums-1998.htm |archivedate=2011-06-11 |df= }}</ref> * [[Marilyn Manson]]: ''[[The Golden Age of Grotesque]]'' (2003): [[Music recording sales certification|gold]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aria.com.au/pages/aria-charts-accreditations-albums-2003.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-02-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/64wuSk4vz?url=http://www.aria.com.au/pages/aria-charts-accreditations-albums-2003.htm |archivedate=2012-01-25 |df= }}</ref> {{col-4}} * [[Marilyn Manson]]: ''[[Lest We Forget: The Best Of]]'' (2004): [[Music recording sales certification|gold]].<ref name="accreditations1">{{cite web|url=http://www.aria.com.au/pages/ARIACharts-Accreditations-2006Albums.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-09-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081217034652/http://www.aria.com.au/pages/ARIACharts-Accreditations-2006Albums.htm |archivedate=2008-12-17 |df= }}</ref> * [[Ministry (band)|Ministry]]: ''[[Psalm 69: The Way to Succeed and the Way to Suck Eggs|Psalm 69]]'' (1992): [[Music recording sales certification|gold]].<ref name="accreditations1"/> {{col-end}}
=== [[New Zealand]] ===
These are the [[Music recording sales certification|certifications]] given by the ''[[Recording Industry Association of New Zealand]]'' from January 10, 1999 onwards:<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rianz.org.nz/rianz/chart.asp |title=The Official New Zealand Music Charts |publisher=rianz.org.nz |accessdate=2007-09-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081204021518/http://www.rianz.org.nz/rianz/chart.asp |archivedate=2008-12-04 |df= }}</ref>

=== [[Finland]] ===
==== EMMA Trophies ====
The EMMA-GAALA Awards are the [[Finland|Finnish]] equivalent to the [[Grammy Awards]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.roadrunnerrecords.com/blabbermouth.net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=68550 |title=LORDI Wins Big At Finland's EMMA GAALA Awards |date=2007-03-10 |publisher=[BLABBERMOUTH.NET] |accessdate=2007-09-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110606230357/http://www.roadrunnerrecords.com/blabbermouth.net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=68550 |archivedate=2011-06-06 |df= }}</ref> [[Rammstein]] won an Emma trophy for "Best International Artist" in 2005.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.emmagaala.fi/arkisto/?vuosi=2005 |title=Arkisto |publisher=[Emma-gaala] |accessdate=2007-09-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070708094828/http://www.emmagaala.fi/arkisto/?vuosi=2005 |archivedate=2007-07-08 |df= }}</ref>

=== [[Germany]] ===
==== ECHO Awards ====
The ''[[ECHO (music award)|ECHO Deutscher Musikpreis]]'' is [[Germany]]'s traditional [[music industry]] award. Here are some [[ECHO (music award)|Echo]] awards and nominations for [[Neue Deutsche Härte|NDH]] artists:
* [[Rammstein]] receive, on March 5, 1998, an [[ECHO (music award)|Echo Award]] for their video "[[Engel (song)|Engel]]", winner in the "Best Video" category.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.echopop.de/kategorie/kat402.htm |archive-url=https://archive.is/20070620105427/http://www.echopop.de/kategorie/kat402.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2007-06-20 |title= ECHO 1998: Musik-Video des Jahres national|publisher= [ECHO 2007 Deutscher Musikpreis - die offizielle Homepage]|accessdate= 2007-09-18}} </ref> * On April 3, 1999, [[Rammstein]] receive the [[ECHO (music award)|Echo Award]] for "Most Successful German Artist Internationally".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.echopop.de/kategorie/kat425.htm |title=ECHO 1999: Künstler/Künstlerin/Gruppe national im Ausland |publisher=[ECHO 2007 Deutscher Musikpreis - die offizielle Homepage] |accessdate=2007-09-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080215083143/http://www.echopop.de/kategorie/kat425.htm |archivedate=February 15, 2008 }}</ref> * [[Rammstein]] accept the "New Rock / Metal / Alternative" [[ECHO (music award)|Echo Award]] on March 7, 2002.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.echopop.de/kategorie/kat114.htm |title=ECHO 2002: Künstler/Künstlerin/Gruppe des Jahres national |publisher=[ECHO 2007 Deutscher Musikpreis - die offizielle Homepage] |accessdate=2007-09-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080214224117/http://www.echopop.de/kategorie/kat114.htm |archivedate=February 14, 2008 }}</ref> * September 10, 2004: For the song cycle "Mein Herz brennt" by Torsten Rasch (based on lyrics and music from [[Rammstein]]), the Dresden Symphony Orchestra is to receive the "ECHO Klassik" in the category "Best debut recording".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.echopop.de/kategorie/kat158.htm |archive-url=https://archive.is/20070620105427/http://www.echopop.de/kategorie/kat158.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2007-06-20 |title= ECHO Klassik 2004: Welt-Ersteinspielung des Jahres|publisher= [ECHO 2007 Deutscher Musikpreis - die offizielle Homepage]|accessdate= 2007-09-23}} </ref> * 2005 was [[Rammstein]]'s [[ECHO (music award)|Echo]] year; the group received ''two'' awards. One was for the "New Rock / Metal / Alternative" category<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.echopop.de/kategorie/kat751.htm |title=ECHO 2005: Künstler/Künstlerin/Gruppe des Jahres national/international |publisher=[ECHO 2007 Deutscher Musikpreis - die offizielle Homepage] |accessdate=2007-09-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060218001250/http://echopop.de/kategorie/kat751.htm |archivedate=February 18, 2006 }}</ref> and the other was for the "Best National Live Act" category.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.echopop.de/kategorie/kat771.htm |title=ECHO 2005: Live-Act national |publisher=[ECHO 2007 Deutscher Musikpreis - die offizielle Homepage] |accessdate=2007-09-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060218001327/http://echopop.de/kategorie/kat771.htm |archivedate=February 18, 2006 }}</ref> * March 12, 2006: [[Rammstein]] won another [[ECHO (music award)|ECHO Award]] and the category was “Best Rock / Alternative”.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.echopop.de/kategorie/kat944.htm |title=ECHO 2006: Künstler/Künstlerin/Gruppe des Jahres national |publisher=[ECHO 2007 Deutscher Musikpreis - die offizielle Homepage] |accessdate=2007-09-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070515051146/http://www.echopop.de/kategorie/kat944.htm |archivedate=May 15, 2007 }}</ref> * [[Oomph!]] were nominated for 2007's "Best Rock / Alternative" category (they didn't win<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.echopop.de/kategorie/kat991.htm |title=ECHO 2007: Künstler/Künstlerin/Gruppe des Jahres Rock/Alternative (national) |publisher=[ECHO 2007 Deutscher Musikpreis - die offizielle Homepage] |accessdate=2007-09-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070830171220/http://www.echopop.de/kategorie/kat991.htm |archivedate=August 30, 2007 }}</ref>).

==== The Edison Award ====
The [[Edison Award]] is the [[Netherlands|Netherlands']] premiere music award.

The ''Spellemannsprisen'' is the [[Norway|Norwegian]] equivalent to the [[Grammy Awards]].<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.mic.no/symfoni/kontakt.nsf/pub_e/bed2000062909593960526894|title= Spellemannsprisen - the Norwegian equivalent to the Grammy Awards|publisher= [MIC - Musikkinformasjonssenteret]|accessdate= 2007-09-18}}</ref> [[The Kovenant]] won an award in the "Hardrock" category for ''[[Nexus Polaris]]'' (1998).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ifpi.no/sok/index_spellemann.htm |title=IFPI Norsk platebransje |publisher=[Spellemannprisen] |accessdate=2007-09-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070613015226/http://www.ifpi.no/sok/index_spellemann.htm |archivedate=2007-06-13 |df= }}</ref> Their third album, ''[[Animatronics]]'' (1999), won for the same category in the following year.

=== United States of America ===
==== Nielsen Soundscans ====
Here's some [[Nielsen Soundscan]] figures for [[Industrial rock]] artists in the [[United States]]. It is important to note that most of these sales figures aren't up-to-date. The [[Nielsen Soundscan|Soundscans]] of [[Ministry (band)|Ministry]]'s discography and the latest by [[Nine Inch Nails|NIN]], [[Rammstein]] and [[Marilyn Manson]] were taken this year. In contrast, the [[Soundscan]] sale numbers from ''[[Broken (Nine Inch Nails EP)|Broken]]'' are almost 14 years old.
